qas.question: If bacteria has flagellum at each end what is the name of the species?
When flagellum is distributed throughout the surface of the cell?
How many proteins is typical flagellum consist os?
How does flagellum function within the cell?

answers.text: uses the electrochemical gradient across the membrane

context: Bacterial species differ in the number and arrangement of flagella on their surface; some have a <a0_0>single flagellum<a0_0/> (monotrichous), a flagellum at each end (<a1_0>amphitrichous<a1_0/>), clusters of flagella at the poles of the cell (lophotrichous), while others have flagella distributed over the entire surface of the cell (<a2_0>peritrichous<a2_0/>). The bacterial flagella is the best-understood motility structure in any organism and is made of about <a3_0>20 proteins<a3_0/>, with approximately another 30 proteins required for its regulation and assembly. The flagellum is a rotating structure driven by a reversible motor at the base that <a4_0>uses the electrochemical gradient across the membrane<a4_0/> for power. This motor drives the motion of the filament, which acts as a propeller.
